You and your coworker are describing two different types of tests, both 
of which are valuable.

+ "Unit" tests test a single unit.  In that case, its enough to know 
that your code has called the database appropriately.  You don't need to 
care about what's in the database.  So you use a Mock Database.  This 
allows you to *quickly* change your code and make sure it still works 
well with a database.

+ "Functional" tests test the workings of the full system.  Several 
times, the "Functional" test can be exactly the same as the "Unit" test, 
though using the real implementation rather than the Mock 
implementation.  This is a pattern I've used on occassion.

My typical pattern for an enhancement is:

+ Unit test the enhancement, Mock-ing as needed.
+ Functional test the enhanced system.

If I *HAD* to choose between the two, I'd choose "Unit" tests.

Why?

+ With only Functional tests, it is much harder to isolate where the 
problem is.  Its also very hard to describe a precise enough functional 
test to isolate the bug in question and avoid regression issues.
+ Performance overhead: It can take time to initialize a database (or 
HttpConnection or whatever).  So if you can use a Mock, you can reduce 
the runtime for non-db specific tests.  In some cases, Compilation can 
be much faster if you don't have to drag in the database-specific 
implementation java files either.
+ Often, a complete and accurate set of Unit tests will mean functional 
tests succeed.  Its unusual (though *certainly* not unheard of) for our 
Functional tests to fail after all of the Unit tests succeed.  So Unit 
tests can provide a sort-of-incomplete Functional test.

NOTE: This is NOT to say I'd eliminate functional tests; they do provide 
value and find bugs and I'd *STRONGLY* encourage using them.  I'm merely 
saying that if I *HAD* to choose....
